ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: How often does your child show objects to you without giving them to you?
If you point to something behind your child that is interesting to see, how often does your child turn his/her head and look behind?
How often does your child let you know that he/she wants an object by looking at you and reaching for the object at the same time?
How often does your child look at you when he/she sees an interesting object?
How often does your child give an object to you to get help operating or opening it?
How often does your child point to an object to enlist your aid in obtaining the object?
When you point and look at something how often does your child look at the same object or event?
How often does your child point to indicate his/her interest in an object or an event?
How often does your child show you an object but not let you take the object from him/her?
How often does your child use reaching as a sign to you to help him/her get an object?
When you look at and point to a toy how often does your child turn and look at the same toy?
How often does your child point to draw your attention to something?
How often does your child hand (or push) an object to you in order to give it to you?
When you point and look at something how often does your child look at the same object, even if that object is behind him/her?
How often does your child point to let you know that he/she wants something else?
When your child sees something interesting how often does he/she look at you like he is/she is trying to share the event with you?
Total Score of Pictorial Infant Communication Scale (PICS)
Which of the following statements best describes your feelings about the questions?
Notes: 0= The questions were difficult to understand.; 1= Some of the questions were easy to understand and others were more difficult to understand; 2= The questions were easy to understand.

ElementDescription: Which, if any, questions were difficult to understand?
Which of the following comments best describes your feelings about the pictures?
Notes: 0= The pictures were not helpful in completing the questionnaire; 1= The pictures were useful for some questions but not for other questions; 2= The pictures clearly reminded me of things my child has done

ElementDescription: Which, if any, pictures were not helpful to you when completing the questionnaire?
How confident are you that your answers accurately represent how often your child demonstrates the behaviors described?
Notes: 0= Not very confident; 1= Somewhat confident; 2= Very confident

ElementDescription: Please write any additional comments you may have about this questionnaire.
